title: Vehicle tax if you have a disability

body.content:
If you get certain benefits because you have a disability, you might be able to:

- pay vehicle tax reduced by 50%
- stop paying vehicle tax

## Pay reduced vehicle tax

You can [apply for a 50% reduction in vehicle tax](/vehicle-tax-disability/apply-for-reduction) if you get the [PIP standard rate mobility component](/pip/what-youll-get).

^ You can’t get a reduction for getting the Disability Living Allowance (DLA) lower rate mobility component. ^

## Paying no vehicle tax

You can [apply to stop paying vehicle tax](/vehicle-tax-disability/apply-for-exemption) if you get the:

- higher rate mobility component of [DLA)](/dla-disability-living-allowance-benefit)
- enhanced rate mobility component of [Personal Independence Payment (PIP)](/pip)
- War Pensioner’s Mobility Supplement
- Armed Forces Independence Payment

The vehicle must:

- be registered in the disabled person’s name or their nominated driver’s name
- only be used for the disabled person’s personal needs - it can’t be used by the nominated driver for their own personal use

*[DLA]: Disability Living Allowance
*[PIP]: Personal Independence Payment
*[AFIP]: Armed Forces Independence Payment

If you get certain benefits because you have a disability, you might be able to:

  • pay vehicle tax reduced by 50%
  • stop paying vehicle tax

Pay reduced vehicle tax

You can apply for a 50% reduction in vehicle tax if you get the PIP standard rate mobility component.

You can’t get a reduction for getting the Disability Living Allowance (DLA) lower rate mobility component.

Paying no vehicle tax

You can apply to stop paying vehicle tax if you get the:

  • higher rate mobility component of DLA)
  • enhanced rate mobility component of Personal Independence Payment (PIP)
  • War Pensioner’s Mobility Supplement
  • Armed Forces Independence Payment

The vehicle must:

  • be registered in the disabled person’s name or their nominated driver’s name
  • only be used for the disabled person’s personal needs - it can’t be used by the nominated driver for their own personal use

parts.title: Apply for a reduction in vehicle tax

body.content:
You can get a 50% reduction in vehicle tax if you get the [Personal Independence Payment (PIP) standard rate mobility component](/pip/what-youll-get).

^ You can’t get a reduction for getting the Disability Living Allowance (DLA) lower rate mobility component. ^

## How to claim

Each time your vehicle tax is due, send all of the following to DVLA:

- your statement of entitlement (it’s at the end of your PIP award letter)
- the vehicle log book (V5C)
- an [application for vehicle tax (V10)](/government/publications/application-for-vehicle-tax-v10)
- an MOT certificate (if your vehicle needs one)
- a cheque or postal order (made out to ‘DVLA, Swansea’) for 50% of the [full rate of vehicle tax](/vehicle-tax-rate-tables) for the vehicle

$A
DVLA  
Swansea  
SA99 1DZ
$A 


*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency
*[PIP]: Personal Independence Payment
*[DLA]: Disability Living Allowance

parts.title: Apply to pay no vehicle tax

body.content:
The way you apply for a vehicle tax exemption depends on whether it’s a new or used vehicle.

^ Applying for an exemption is sometimes known as putting a vehicle into the 'disabled tax class'. ^

## New vehicles

If you’re buying a new vehicle, take a 'certificate of entitlement' for one of these benefits to the car dealership: 

- Disability Living Allowance (DLA)
- Personal Independence Payment (PIP)
- War Pensioner’s Mobility Supplement
- Armed Forces Independence Payment (AFIP)

^ If the vehicle is registered in Northern Ireland, you also need to take a valid insurance certificate or cover note. ^

## Used vehicles

Apply for a vehicle tax exemption at a [Post Office](http://www.postoffice.co.uk/branch-finder) that deals with vehicle tax. 

You need to take:

- a filled in [application for a log book (V62)](/government/publications/application-for-a-vehicle-registration-certificate)
- the log book (V5C), or a green 'new keeper's details' slip (V5C/2) if you’ve just bought the vehicle
- a ‘certificate of entitlement’ for either DLA, PIP, War Pensioner’s Mobility Supplement or AFIP - write the vehicle's number plate in the top right-hand corner
- a valid MOT certificate (if your vehicle needs one)

^ If the vehicle is registered in Northern Ireland, you also need to take a valid insurance certificate or cover note. ^

### What happens next

s1. The Post Office sends your documents to DVLA.
s2. You’ll get confirmation from DVLA within 10 working days that the change has been made.
s3. DVLA will send you an updated log book within 6 weeks.
s4. If you were paying vehicle tax for the vehicle, you’ll automatically get a refund cheque for any full months left. If you pay by Direct Debit, it’ll be cancelled automatically.


You can still use your vehicle while your application is being processed. [Call DVLA](/contact-the-dvla/y/vehicle-registration-and-v5c-certificates-log-books) if the new log book hasn’t arrived after 6 weeks.

## Renewing your vehicle tax

You still need to [tax your vehicle](/vehicle-tax) when it's due to run out, but you won't need to pay.

^ If you have a car through the [Motability Scheme](http://www.motability.co.uk/), they'll tax it for you each year, unless you tell them you want to do it yourself. ^


*[DLA]: Disability Living Allowance
*[PIP]: Personal Independence Payment
*[AFIP]: Armed Forces Independence Payment
*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency

Applying for an exemption is sometimes known as putting a vehicle into the ‘disabled tax class’.

New vehicles

  • Disability Living Allowance (DLA)
  • Personal Independence Payment (PIP)
  • War Pensioner’s Mobility Supplement
  • Armed Forces Independence Payment (AFIP)

If the vehicle is registered in Northern Ireland, you also need to take a valid insurance certificate or cover note.

Apply for a vehicle tax exemption at a Post Office that deals with vehicle tax.

You need to take:

  • a filled in application for a log book (V62)
  • the log book (V5C), or a green ‘new keeper’s details’ slip (V5C/2) if you’ve just bought the vehicle
  • a ‘certificate of entitlement’ for either DLA, PIP, War Pensioner’s Mobility Supplement or AFIP - write the vehicle’s number plate in the top right-hand corner
  • a valid MOT certificate (if your vehicle needs one)

If the vehicle is registered in Northern Ireland, you also need to take a valid insurance certificate or cover note.

What happens next

  1. The Post Office sends your documents to DVLA.

  2. You’ll get confirmation from DVLA within 10 working days that the change has been made.

  3. DVLA will send you an updated log book within 6 weeks.

  4. If you were paying vehicle tax for the vehicle, you’ll automatically get a refund cheque for any full months left. If you pay by Direct Debit, it’ll be cancelled automatically.

You can still use your vehicle while your application is being processed. Call DVLA if the new log book hasn’t arrived after 6 weeks.

Renewing your vehicle tax

You still need to tax your vehicle when it’s due to run out, but you won’t need to pay.

If you have a car through the Motability Scheme, they’ll tax it for you each year, unless you tell them you want to do it yourself.

parts.title: Changing the vehicle or registered keeper

body.content:
If you change your vehicle or the registered keeper of the vehicle, you need to get a new certificate of entitlement for one of these benefits: 

- Disability Living Allowance (DLA)
- Personal Independence Payment (PIP)
- War Pensioner’s Mobility Supplement
- Armed Forces Independence Payment (AFIP)

## How to get a replacement certificate

Call the number that deals with the benefit you get.

$C
**DLA (England, Scotland and Wales)**   
Telephone: 0345 712 3456   
Textphone: 0345 722 4433  
Monday to Friday, 8am to 6pm  
[Find out about call charges](/call-charges)
$C

$C
**DLA (Northern Ireland)**   
Telephone: 0300 123 3356  
Textphone: 028 9031 1092  
Monday to Friday, 9am to 5pm  
[Find out about call charges](/call-charges)
$C


$C
**PIP and AFIP**  
Telephone: 0345 850 3322  
Textphone: 0345 601 6677  
Monday to Friday, 8am to 6pm  
[Find out about call charges](/call-charges)
$C


$C
**War Pensioner’s Mobility Supplement**  
Telephone: 0800 085 3600  
Monday to Thursday, 7:30am to 6:30pm  
Friday, 7:30am to 5pm  
[Find out about call charges](/call-charges)
$C

## Changing the vehicle

s1. [Apply to stop paying vehicle tax](/vehicle-tax-disability/apply-for-exemption) for the new vehicle. You'll need the replacement certificate of benefit entitlement.
s2. The new registered keeper of your old vehicle needs to tell DVLA [the vehicle is no longer being used by a disabled person](/vehicle-tax-disability/stop-exemption).


^ You can only have one vehicle tax exemption at any one time. ^

## Changing the vehicle's registered keeper 

You need to get a new log book and update the vehicle tax exemption at a [Post Office](http://www.postoffice.co.uk/branch-finder) that deals with vehicle tax. 

Take the following documents:

- a filled in [application for a log book (V62)](/government/publications/application-for-a-vehicle-registration-certificate)
- the log book (V5C) or the green ‘new keeper’s details’ slip (V5C/2)
- a ‘certificate of entitlement’ to DLA, PIP, War Pensioner’s Mobility Supplement or AFIP - write the vehicle's number plate in the top right-hand corner
- a valid MOT certificate (if your vehicle needs one)

^ If the vehicle is registered in Northern Ireland, you also need to take a valid insurance certificate. ^

### What happens next

s1. The Post Office sends your documents to DVLA.
s2. You’ll get a confirmation from DVLA within 10 working days that the change has been made.
s3. DVLA will send you an updated log book within 6 weeks.


You can still use your vehicle while your application is being processed. [Call DVLA](/contact-the-dvla/y/vehicle-registration-and-v5c-certificates-log-books) if the new log book hasn’t arrived after 6 weeks.


*[DLA]: Disability Living Allowance
*[PIP]: Personal Independence Payment
*[AFIP]: Armed Forces Independence Payment
*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency

If you change your vehicle or the registered keeper of the vehicle, you need to get a new certificate of entitlement for one of these benefits:

  • Disability Living Allowance (DLA)
  • Personal Independence Payment (PIP)
  • War Pensioner’s Mobility Supplement
  • Armed Forces Independence Payment (AFIP)

How to get a replacement certificate

Call the number that deals with the benefit you get.

DLA (England, Scotland and Wales)
Telephone: 0345 712 3456

Changing the vehicle

  1. Apply to stop paying vehicle tax for the new vehicle. You’ll need the replacement certificate of benefit entitlement.

  2. The new registered keeper of your old vehicle needs to tell DVLA the vehicle is no longer being used by a disabled person.

You can only have one vehicle tax exemption at any one time.

Changing the vehicle’s registered keeper

You need to get a new log book and update the vehicle tax exemption at a Post Office that deals with vehicle tax.

Take the following documents:

  • a filled in application for a log book (V62)
  • the log book (V5C) or the green ‘new keeper’s details’ slip (V5C/2)
  • a ‘certificate of entitlement’ to DLA, PIP, War Pensioner’s Mobility Supplement or AFIP - write the vehicle’s number plate in the top right-hand corner
  • a valid MOT certificate (if your vehicle needs one)

If the vehicle is registered in Northern Ireland, you also need to take a valid insurance certificate.

What happens next

  1. The Post Office sends your documents to DVLA.

  2. You’ll get a confirmation from DVLA within 10 working days that the change has been made.

  3. DVLA will send you an updated log book within 6 weeks.

You can still use your vehicle while your application is being processed. Call DVLA if the new log book hasn’t arrived after 6 weeks.

parts.title: If your vehicle stops being used by a disabled person

body.content:
You must tell DVLA if your vehicle stops being used by a disabled person, and start paying vehicle tax again.

^ This is sometimes known as 'changing from the disabled to private tax class'. ^

## How to remove the exemption

Apply at a [Post Office](http://www.postoffice.co.uk/branch-finder) that deals with vehicle tax. 

You need to take:

- the log book (V5C) in your name, or a green 'new keeper's details' slip (V5C/2) if you’ve just bought the vehicle
- your vehicle tax reminder letter (V11), if you have one
- an MOT certificate (if your vehicle needs one)
- payment for the [vehicle tax](/vehicle-tax-rate-tables)

If your vehicle is registered in Northern Ireland, you also need to take a valid insurance certificate. 

^ If you don’t have the log book or V5C/2, download and fill in an [application for a vehicle log book (V62)](/government/publications/application-for-a-vehicle-registration-certificate). Take it to the Post Office with the £25 fee. ^

## What happens next

s1. The Post Office sends your documents to DVLA.
s2. You’ll get a confirmation from DVLA within 10 working days that the change has been made.
s3. DVLA will send you an updated log book within 6 weeks. 


You can still use your vehicle while your application is being processed. [Call DVLA](/contact-the-dvla/y/vehicle-registration-and-v5c-certificates-log-books) if the new log book hasn’t arrived after 6 weeks.

The next time your vehicle tax is due, you can [tax it online](/vehicle-tax) as normal.

*[DVLA]: Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency

You must tell DVLA if your vehicle stops being used by a disabled person, and start paying vehicle tax again.

This is sometimes known as ‘changing from the disabled to private tax class’.

How to remove the exemption

Apply at a Post Office that deals with vehicle tax.

You need to take:

  • the log book (V5C) in your name, or a green ‘new keeper’s details’ slip (V5C/2) if you’ve just bought the vehicle
  • your vehicle tax reminder letter (V11), if you have one
  • an MOT certificate (if your vehicle needs one)
  • payment for the vehicle tax

If your vehicle is registered in Northern Ireland, you also need to take a valid insurance certificate.

If you don’t have the log book or V5C/2, download and fill in an application for a vehicle log book (V62). Take it to the Post Office with the £25 fee.

What happens next

  1. The Post Office sends your documents to DVLA.

  2. You’ll get a confirmation from DVLA within 10 working days that the change has been made.

  3. DVLA will send you an updated log book within 6 weeks.

You can still use your vehicle while your application is being processed. Call DVLA if the new log book hasn’t arrived after 6 weeks.

The next time your vehicle tax is due, you can tax it online as normal.
